newsitem.title: JORDAN: Arab Bank profits up 18 percent in 1996.
newsitem.headline: Arab Bank profits up 18 percent in 1996.

text.p: Arab Bank, one of the region's major financial institutions, reported on Wednesday a 18 percent rise in 1996 net profits to a record 95.7 million dinars ($135.2 million).

"This is our best result since our founding and is due to better results in our branches in Europe, the U.S., the Far East and the Gulf states," Abdul-Majeed Shoman, chairman of Arab Bank plc, told Reuters.
The bank's total balance sheet rose by 4.3 percent to 13.481 billion dinars at end of December 1996 against 12.927 billion dinars in December 1995.
The results exclude subsidiaries and large holdings in Arab banks which are under the Arab Bank Group umbrella, with a total balance sheet of above $22.9 billion in 1995.

Customer deposits rose by 10 percent to 6.396 billion dinars at end of 1996 from 5.797 billion dinars a year before. Loans rose 12 percent to 4.163 billion dinars against 3.711 billion dinars in 1995.
Total shareholders equity rose to 630 million dinars from 552 million dinars at end of 1995, the bank's balance sheet showed.
Long-term investments rose 58 percent to 727.6 million in 1996 from 450 million in 1995.
Shoman said Arab Bank, with over 300 branches globally, had expanded its international presence with two new representative offices in Shanghai, China and in Santiago, Chile.

The bank's shares, which account for over a third of the Amman Financial Market's capitalisation, have risen since the government unveiled late last year a package of reforms that include cancelling a 15 percent tax levied on companies' capital increases.
Shoman said the bank would keep a pledge to shareholders to distribute a bonus share once the tax is cancelled under new companies law due to be passed by parliament by April.
The bank, established in 1930, and the oldest Palestinian bank, also extended further its operations in Palestinian self-rule areas to a total of 16 branches in the West Bank and Gaza.
The bank joined in a 55 percent equity shareholding last year in the $15 million capitalised Arab Palestine Investment Bank which is due to begin operations soon.
Arab Bank has captured nearly 60 percent of the market share of a total $1.7 billion of bank deposits in the West Bank and Gaza since it began operations there two years ago.

Arab Bank was a latecomer to a banking boom that began after Middle East peace accords in 1993 allowed Jordanian banks to resume operations after a 26-year absence which followed Israel's seizure of the West Bank.
